Shame on Fox for not reporting the whole news.  European channels covered the story in detail.  It was a Soviet-era TU-141 drone, which weighs about six tons and is launched from a catapult carrier.   It lands using parachutes.  The deployed parachute was found near the crash site.   

European news channels have reported that for over 20 years the only country in the world that operates TU-141 drones is Ukraine.   Even at the end of the USSR 33 years ago, there were no TU-141 drones deployed within the Russia SSR because the border of the USSR  was hundreds of miles to the West.   Drones and other active military elements were deployed where the military action was expected to be, in Ukraine, Belarus, and the Baltics, which were on the border with the West.    Russia over 25 years ago moved to much newer drones than obsolete TU-141s.

Almost all of Kiev's air force, including the two or three dozen drones they bought from Turkey, was wiped out in the opening 15 minutes of the war by precision strikes from Russia.  All evidence indicates this drone was pulled from inactive storage by Kiev's forces, fueled, and launched, with the Soviet era guidance system failing and sending it out of Ukraine to the West.  

It's a classic example of Kiev not giving a hoot about targeting, just the same way they launch artillery strikes at Donbass into civilian areas, because those are easy to hit, unlike trying precision strikes on military targets.
